kerning-pairs-ligatures.description: Currently non-standard method of improving kerning pairs & ligatures using `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Android browser versions is due to a serious bug where `text-rendering: optimizeLegibility` causes custom web fonts to not render.

iframe-seamless.title: seamless attribute for iframes
iframe-seamless.description: The seamless attribute makes an iframe's contents actually part of a page, and adopts the styles from its hosting page.
iframe-seamless.notes: Chrome 20-26 had partial support behind a flag, though this was [later removed](http://crbug.com/229421).

notes_by_num.1: Hides the border of seamless iframes and recognizes the 'seamless' DOM property, but does not provide actual support.

css-image-orientation.title: CSS3 image-orientation
css-image-orientation.description: CSS property used generally to fix the intended orientation of an image. This can be done using 90 degree increments or based on the image's EXIF data using the "from-image" value.
css-image-orientation.notes: Opening the image in a new tab in Chrome results in the image shown in the orientation according to the EXIF data.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in iOS refers to the browser using EXIF data by default, though it does not actually support the property.

picture.title: Picture element
picture.description: A responsive images method to control which image resource a user agent presents to a user, based on resolution, media query and/or support for a particular image format

links.title: Picturefill - polyfill for picture, srcset, sizes, and more

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Enabled in Opera through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in opera://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled in Firefox by setting the about:config preference dom.image.picture.enable to true

woff2.title: WOFF 2.0 - Web Open Font Format
woff2.description: TrueType/OpenType font that provides better compression than WOFF 1.0.

notes_by_num.1: Default 'enabled' for Firefox version 39+, but versions 37-38 will need to set a flag to 'true' to [use WOFF2](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@font-face#Browser_compatibility).

text-size-adjust.title: CSS text-size-adjust
text-size-adjust.description: On mobile devices, the text-size-adjust CSS property allows Web authors to control if and how the text-inflating algorithm is applied to the textual content of the element it is applied to.

web-animation.title: Web Animations API
web-animation.description: Lets you create animations that are run in the browser and as well as inspect and manipulate animations created through declarative means like CSS.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to basic support of `element.animate()`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to basic support of `element.animate()` and [playback control of AnimationPlayer](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5633748733263872)
notes_by_num.3: Partial support in Firefox is detailed in [Are we animated yet?](https://birtles.github.io/areweanimatedyet/)

resource-timing.title: Resource Timing
resource-timing.description: Method to help web developers to collect complete timing information related to resources on a document.

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the dom.enable_resource_timing flag

custom-elements.title: Custom Elements
custom-elements.description: Method of defining and using new types of DOM elements in a document.

links.title: W3C Editor's Draft spec (closer to current implementations)
HTML5Rocks - Custom Elements: defining new elements in HTML
Chromium tracking bug: Implement Custom Elements
Firefox tracking bug: Implement Custom Elements (from Web Components)
IE Web Platform Status and Roadmap: Custom Elements

notes_by_num.1: Enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.enabled" preference in about:config

imports.title: HTML Imports
imports.description: Method of including and reusing HTML documents in other HTML documents.

links.title: HTML5Rocks - HTML Imports: #include for the web
Chromium tracking bug: Implement HTML Imports
Firefox tracking bug: Implement HTML Imports
IE Web Platform Status and Roadmap: HTML Imports

notes_by_num.1: Firefox [has no plans to support HTML imports](https://hacks.mozilla.org/2014/12/mozilla-and-web-components/) though for now it can be enabled through the "dom.webcomponents.enabled" preference in about:config
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Enable HTML Imports" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.4: Enabled through the "Enable HTML Imports" flag in opera://flags
notes_by_num.5: Enabled through the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag in opera://flags

input-file-multiple.title: Multiple file selection
input-file-multiple.description: Allows users to select multiple files in the file picker.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported on Android 4.x and below, presumably an OS limitation. Only seems to work in Android 5.x for the Chrome browser.

atob-btoa.title: Base64 encoding and decoding
atob-btoa.description: Utility functions for of encoding and decoding strings to and from base 64: window.atob() and window.btoa().

css-appearance.title: CSS Appearance
css-appearance.description: The `appearance` property defines how elements (particularly form controls) appear by default. By setting the value to `none` the default appearance can be entirely redefined using other CSS properties.

notes_by_num.1: The appearance property is supported with the `none` value, but not `auto`. Webkit, Blink, and Gecko browsers also support additional vendor specific values.
notes_by_num.2: Microsoft Edge and IE Mobile support this property with the `-webkit-` prefix, rather than `-ms-` for interop reasons.

objectrtc.title: Object RTC (ORTC) API for WebRTC
objectrtc.description: Enables mobile endpoints to talk to servers and web browsers with Real-Time Communications (RTC) capabilities via native and simple JavaScript APIs

links.title: Bringing Interoperable Real-Time Communications to the Web

objectrtc.notes: ORTC is often dubbed WebRTC 1.1. It is possible to make ORTC communicate with WebRTC 1.0 endpoints. See [WebRTC 1.0](http://caniuse.com/#feat=rtcpeerconnection) for support details for that API.

css-background-offsets.title: CSS background-position edge offsets
css-background-offsets.description: Allows CSS background images to be positioned relative to the specified edge using the 3 to 4 value syntax. For example: `background-position: right 5px bottom 5px;` for positioning 5px from the bottom-right corner.

css-supports-api.title: CSS.supports() API
css-supports-api.description: The CSS.supports() static methods returns a Boolean value indicating if the browser supports a given CSS feature, or not.

links.title: Native CSS Feature Detection via the @supports Rule

css-supports-api.notes:
See also [@supports in CSS](#feat=css-featurequeries)

See the [WebKit Bug](http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/142739) for status in Safari

notes_by_num.1: Opera 12 uses a different method name('window.supportsCSS')

css-touch-action.title: CSS touch-action property
css-touch-action.description: touch-action is a CSS property that controls filtering of gesture events, providing developers with a declarative mechanism to selectively disable touch scrolling (in one or both axes), pinch-zooming or double-tap-zooming.

links.title: What Exactly Is..... The 300ms Click Delay
What Exactly Is..... The 300ms Click Delay(Chinese)

notes_by_num.1: Supported in Firefox behind the `layout.css.touch_action.enabled` flag, Firefox for Windows 8 Touch ('Metro') enabled by default.
notes_by_num.2: IE10+ has already supported these property which are not in standard at present such as'pinch-zoom','double-tap-zoom','cross-slide-x','cross-slide-y'.

autofocus.title: Autofocus attribute
autofocus.description: Allows a form field to be immediately focused on page load.
autofocus.notes: While not supported in iOS Safari, it does work in iOS WebViews.

css-clip-path.title: CSS clip-path property
css-clip-path.description: Method of defining the visible region of an element using SVG or a shape definition.

links.title: Codepen Example Clipping an Image with a Polygon

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to only supporting the `url()` syntax.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting shapes and the `url(#foo)` syntax for inline SVG, but not shapes in external SVGs.

getrandomvalues.title: crypto.getRandomValues()
getrandomvalues.description: Method of generating cryptographically random values.

screen-orientation.title: Screen Orientation
screen-orientation.description: Provides the ability to read the screen orientation state, to be informed when this state changes, and to be able to lock the screen orientation to a specific state.
screen-orientation.notes: Partial support refers to an [older version](http://www.w3.org/TR/2014/WD-screen-orientation-20140220/) of the draft specification, and the spec has undergone significant changes since, for example renaming the `screen.lockOrientation` method to `screen.orientation.lock`.

font-loading.title: CSS Font Loading
font-loading.description: This CSS module defines a scripting interface to font faces in CSS, allowing font faces to be easily created and loaded from script. It also provides methods to track the loading status of an individual font, or of all the fonts on an entire page.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.font-loading-api.enabled` flag. Enabled by default in Firefox 41. See [this bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1149381)

font-unicode-range.title: Font unicode-range subsetting
font-unicode-range.description: This @font-face descriptor defines the set of Unicode codepoints that may be supported by the font face for which it is declared. The descriptor value is a comma-delimited list of Unicode range (<urange>) values. The union of these ranges defines the set of codepoints that serves as a hint for user agents when deciding whether or not to download a font resource for a given text run.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

font-unicode-range.notes: Partial support indicates that unnecessary code-ranges are downloaded by the browser - see [browser test matrix](https://docs.google.com/a/chromium.org/spreadsheets/d/18h-1gaosu4-KYxH8JUNL6ZDuOsOKmWfauoai3CS3hPY/edit?pli=1#gid=0).

notes_by_num.1: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.unicode-range.enabled` flag

gamepad.title: Gamepad API
gamepad.description: API to support input from USB gamepad controllers through JavaScript.

css-font-stretch.title: CSS font-stretch
css-font-stretch.description: If a font has multiple types of variations based on the width of characters, the `font-stretch` property allows the appropriate one to be selected. The property in itself does not cause the browser to stretch to a font.

font-size-adjust.title: CSS font-size-adjust
font-size-adjust.description: Method of adjusting the font size in a matter that relates to the height of lowercase vs. uppercase letters. This makes it easier to set the size of fallback fonts.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Enabled in Chrome through the "experimental Web Platform features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.2: Does not appear to work on Firefox mobile, despite recognition of the property.

link-icon-png.title: PNG favicons
link-icon-png.description: Icon used by browsers to identify a webpage or site. While all browsers support the `.ico` format, the PNG format can be preferable.

links.title: Detailed info on favicons for various uses

link-icon-png.notes:
Win8/IE10+ and iOS Safari support other types of icons for webpages too, using alternate tags.

See also [SVG favicons](#feat=link-icon-svg).

notes_by_num.1: If both ICO and PNG are available, will use ICO over PNG if ICO has better matching sizes set.
notes_by_num.2: If both ICO and PNG are available, will ALWAYS use ICO file, regardless of sizes set.
notes_by_num.3: If multiple formats are available, will use the last one loaded, regardless of sizes (effectively picks at random).
notes_by_num.4: Does not use favicons at all (but may have alternative for bookmarks, etc.).

link-icon-svg.title: SVG favicons
link-icon-svg.description: Icon used by browsers to identify a webpage or site. While all browsers support the `.ico` format, the SVG format can be preferable to more easily support higher resolutions or larger icons.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Does not use favicons at all
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in Firefox before version 41 refers to only loading the SVG favicon the first time, but not [on subsequent loads](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=366324#c14).
notes_by_num.3: Safari 9 has support for "[pinned tab](https://developer.apple.com/library/prerelease/mac/releasenotes/General/WhatsNewInSafari/Articles/Safari_9.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40014305-CH9-SW20)" SVG icons, but this requires an unofficial `rel="mask-icon"` to be set and only works for all-black icons on Pinned Tabs.
notes_by_num.4: Firefox [requires](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=366324#c50) the served mime-type to be 'image/svg+xml'.

css-media-resolution.title: Media Queries: resolution feature
css-media-resolution.description: Allows a media query to be set based on the device pixels used per CSS unit. While the standard uses `min`/`max-resolution` for this, some browsers support the older non-standard `device-pixel-ratio` media query.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `dpi` unit, but does not support `dppx` or `dpcm` units.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox before 16 supports only `dpi` unit, but you can set `2dppx` per `min--moz-device-pixel-ratio: 2`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the non-standard `min`/`max-device-pixel-ratio`

xml-serializer.title: DOM Parsing and Serialization
xml-serializer.description: Various DOM parsing and serializing functions, specifically `DOMParser`, `XMLSerializer`, `innerHTML`, `outerHTML` and `adjacentHTML`.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to lacking support for `parseFromString` on the DOMParser.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in older IE refers to only supporting `innerHTML`, nothing else.

css-image-set.title: CSS image-set
css-image-set.description: Method of letting the browser pick the most appropriate CSS background image from a given set, primarily for high PPI screens.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-boxdecorationbreak.title: CSS box-decoration-break
css-boxdecorationbreak.description: Controls whether the box's margins, borders, padding, and other decorations wrap the broken edges of the box fragments (when the box is split by a break (page/column/region/line).

links.title: Demo of effect on box border
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to working for inline elements but not across column or page breaks.

object-observe.title: Object.observe data binding
object-observe.description: Method for data binding, part of the ECMAScript 7 proposals

css-at-counter-style.title: CSS Counter Styles
css-at-counter-style.description: The @counter-style CSS at-rule allows custom counter styles to be defined. A @counter-style rule defines how to convert a counter value into a string representation.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to lacking support for [image symbols](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1024179)

css-page-break.title: CSS page-break properties
css-page-break.description: Properties to control the way elements are broken across (printed) pages.

links.title: Latest fragmentation specification (includes column & region breaks)

css-page-break.notes: Not all mobile browsers offer print support; support listed for these is based on browser engine capability.

notes_by_num.1: Supports the `page-break-*` alias from the CSS 2.1 specification, but not the `break-*` properties from the latest spec.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support `avoid` for `page-break-before` & `page-break-after` (only `page-break-inside`).
notes_by_num.3: Treats the `left` and `right` values like `always`.

css-placeholder-shown.title: :placeholder-shown CSS pseudo-class
css-placeholder-shown.description: Input elements can sometimes show placeholder text as a hint to the user on what to type in. See, for example, the placeholder attribute in HTML5. The :placeholder-shown pseudo-class matches an input element that is showing such placeholder text.
css-placeholder-shown.notes:
For support of styling the actual placeholder text itself, see [CSS ::placeholder](http://caniuse.com/#feat=css-placeholder)

Support currently exists in [WebKit Nightly](http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/172826)

broadcastchannel.title: BroadcastChannel
broadcastchannel.description: BroadcastChannel allows scripts from the same origin but other browsing contexts (windows, workers) to send each other messages.

css-crisp-edges.title: Crisp edges/pixelated images
css-crisp-edges.description: Forces images to be scaled with an algorithm that preserves contrast and edges in the image, without smoothing colors or introduce blur. This is intended for images such as pixel art. Official values that accomplish this for the `image-rendering` property are `crisp-edges` and `pixelated`.
css-crisp-edges.notes: Note that prefixes apply to the value (e.g. `-moz-crisp-edges`), not the `image-rendering` property.

notes_by_num.1: Supported using the non-standard value `-webkit-optimize-contrast`
notes_by_num.2: Internet Explorer accomplishes support using the non-standard declaration `-ms-interpolation-mode: nearest-neighbor`
notes_by_num.3: Supports the `crisp-edges` value, but not `pixelated`.

css-text-align-last.title: CSS3 text-align-last
css-text-align-last.description: CSS property to describe how the last line of a block or a line right before a forced line break when `text-align` is `justify`.

notes_by_num.1: In Internet Explorer, the start and end values are not supported.
notes_by_num.2: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in chrome://flags
notes_by_num.3: Enabled through the "Enable Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in opera://flags

css-logical-props.title: CSS Logical Properties
css-logical-props.description: Use start/end properties that depend on LTR or RTL writing direction instead of left/right

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

notes_by_num.1: Only supports the *-start, and *-end values for `margin`, `border` and `padding`, not the inline/block type values as defined in the spec.
notes_by_num.2: Like #1 but also supports `*-before` and `*-end` for `*-block-start` and `*-block-end` properties as well as `start` and `end` values for `text-align`

notes_by_num.1: Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the `dom.fetch.enabled` flag.
notes_by_num.2: Only available in Chrome and Opera within ServiceWorkers.
notes_by_num.3: Available in Chrome and Opera within Window and Workers by enabling the "Experimental Web Platform Features" flag in `chrome://flags`
notes_by_num.4: Firefox <40 is not completely conforming to the specs and does not respect the <base> tag for relative URIs in fetch requests. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1161625

referrer-policy.title: Referrer Policy
referrer-policy.description: Allow control of HTTP referrers via the referrer meta tag.

notes_by_num.1: Supports an [older draft](https://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Meta_referrer) of the specification with `never`, `always`, `origin` & `default` values.

background-attachment.title: CSS background-attachment
background-attachment.description: Method of defining how a background image is attached to a scrollable element. Values include `scroll` (default), `fixed` and `local`.
background-attachment.notes: Most mobile devices have a delay in updating the background position after scrolling a page with `fixed` backgrounds.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to supporting `fixed` but not `local`
notes_by_num.2: Partial support refers to supporting `local` but not `fixed`

currentcolor.title: CSS currentColor value
currentcolor.description: A CSS value that will apply the existing `color` value to other properties like `background-color`, etc.

input-pattern.title: Pattern attribute for input fields
input-pattern.description: Allows validation of an input field based on a given regular expression pattern.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support refers to not displaying a message for invalid patterns
notes_by_num.2: Safari browsers support the `pattern` attribute but will still allow forms to be submitted if the pattern is incorrect. See the [form validation data](http://caniuse.com/#feat=form-validation) for details.

registerprotocolhandler.title: Custom protocol handling
registerprotocolhandler.description: Method of allowing a webpage to handle a given protocol using `navigator.registerProtocolHandler`. This allows certain URLs to be opened by a given web application, for example `mailto:` addresses can be opened by a webmail client.

notes_by_num.1: Supports protocols `mailto`, `mms`, `nntp`, `rtsp`, and `webcal` but requires custom protocols to start with `web+`

css-snappoints.title: CSS Scroll snap points
css-snappoints.description: CSS technique that allows customizable scrolling experiences like pagination of carousels by setting defined snap points.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE10 refers to support limited to touch screens.
notes_by_num.2: Partial support in IE11 [documented here](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/444684/openwebref/CSS/scroll-snap-points/support.html)
notes_by_num.3: Can be enabled in Firefox using the `layout.css.scroll-snap.enabled` flag in `about:config`
notes_by_num.4: Partial support in Safari refers to not supporting the `none` keyword in `scroll-snap-points-x`, `scroll-snap-points-y` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`, and length keywords (`top`, `right`, etc.) in `scroll-snap-destination` and `scroll-snap-coordinate`.

input-minlength.title: Minimum length attribute for input fields
input-minlength.description: Declares a lower bound on the number of characters a user can input.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-media-interaction.title: Media Queries: interaction media features
css-media-interaction.description: Allows a media query to be set based on the presence and accuracy of the user's pointing device, and whether they have the ability to hover over elements on the page. This includes the `pointer`, `any-pointer`, `hover`, and `any-hover` media features.

links.title: Potential use cases for script, hover and pointer CSS Level 4 Media Features
Interaction Media Features and their potential (for incorrect assumptions)

ime.title: Input Method Editor API
ime.description: Provides scripted access to the Input Method Editor (IME). An IME is often used to input characters from East Asian languages by typing roman characters and selecting from the resulting suggestions.

links.title: Building Better Input Experience for East Asian Users with the IME API in IE11

notes_by_num.1: Prefixed implementation uses `msGetInputContext()` method from an earlier version of the spec to get the `InputMethodContext`, rather than the `inputMethodContext` attribute. Also includes support for `getCompositionAlternatives()` from the latest Editor'

font-smooth.title: CSS font-smooth
font-smooth.description: Controls the application of anti-aliasing when fonts are rendered.

links.title: Old version of W3C recommendation containing font-smooth

font-smooth.notes: Though present in early (2002) drafts of CSS3 Fonts, `font-smooth` has been removed from this specification and is currently not on the standard track.

notes_by_num.1: Webkit implements something similar with a different name `-webkit-font-smoothing` and different values: `none`, `antialiased` and `subpixel-antialiased`.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox implements something similar with a different name `-moz-osx-font-smoothing` and different values: `auto`, `inherit`, `unset`, `grayscale`.
notes_by_num.3: Works only on Mac OS X platform.

audiotracks.title: Audio Tracks
audiotracks.description: Method of specifying and selecting between multiple audio tracks. Useful for providing audio descriptions, director's commentary, additional languages, alternative takes, etc.

videotracks.title: Video Tracks
videotracks.description: Method of specifying and selecting between multiple video tracks. Useful for providing sign language tracks, burnt-in captions or subtitles, alternative camera angles, etc.

contentsecuritypolicy2.title: Content Security Policy Level 2
contentsecuritypolicy2.description: Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by whitelisting allowed sources of script, style, and other resources. CSP 2 adds hash-source, nonce-source, and five new directives

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 31-34 is missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.2: Firefox 35 is missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.3: Firefox 36+ is missing the plugin-types and child-src directives.
notes_by_num.4: Chrome 36-38 & Opera 23-25 are missing the plugin-types, child-src, frame-ancestors, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.5: Chrome 39 and Opera 26 are missing the plugin-types, child-src, base-uri, and form-action directives.
notes_by_num.6: Firefox 38 on Android is missing the child-src directive.

permissions-api.title: Permissions API
permissions-api.description: High-level JavaScript API for checking and requesting permissions

http2.title: HTTP/2 protocol
http2.description: Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Originally started out from the SPDY protocol, now standardized as HTTP version 2.
http2.notes: See also support for [the SPDY protocol](http://caniuse.com/#feat=spdy), precursor of HTTP2.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in IE11 refers to being limited to Windows 10.

font-kerning.title: CSS3 font-kerning
font-kerning.description: Controls the usage of the kerning information (spacing between letters) stored in the font. Note that this only affects OpenType fonts with kerning information, it has no effect on other fonts.
font-kerning.notes: Browsers with support for [font feature settings](http://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature) can also set kerning value.

notes_by_num.1: Disabled by default, can be enabled using preference layout.css.font-features.enabled - defaulting to true on Nightly and Aurora only.

jpeg2000.title: JPEG 2000 image format
jpeg2000.description: JPEG 2000 (JP2) was created by the Joint Photographic Experts Group committee in 2000 with the intention of superseding their original discrete cosine transform-based JPEG standard (created in 1992) with a newly designed, wavelet-based method. It offers some advantages in image fidelity over standard JPEG.

notes_by_num.1: Not supported by Safari for Windows

upgradeinsecurerequests.title: Upgrade Insecure Requests
upgradeinsecurerequests.description: Declare that browsers should transparently upgrade HTTP resources on a website to HTTPS.
upgradeinsecurerequests.notes: The HTTP header is `Content-Security-Policy: upgrade-insecure-requests`. Alternatively, the HTML tag is `<meta http-equiv="Content-Security-Policy" content="upgrade-insecure-requests">`.

publickeypinning.title: Public Key Pinning
publickeypinning.description: Declare that a website's HTTPS certificate should only be treated as valid if the public key is contained in a specified list to prevent MITM attacks that use valid CA-issued certificates.
publickeypinning.notes: The HTTP header syntax is 'Public-Key-Pins: pin-sha256="base64=="; max-age=expireTime [; includeSubdomains][; report-uri="reportURI"]'.

input-email-tel-url.title: Email, telephone & URL input types
input-email-tel-url.description: Text input fields intended for email addresses, telephone numbers or URLs. Particularly useful in combination with [form validation](http://caniuse.com/#feat=form-validation)
input-email-tel-url.notes: Browsers without support for these types will fall back to using the "text" type.

notes_by_num.1: Does not provide an email-specific keyboard for email addresses

fieldset-disabled.title: disabled attribute of the fieldset element
fieldset-disabled.description: Allows disabling all of the form control descendants of a fieldset via a `disabled` attribute on the fieldset element itself.

notes_by_num.1: Text inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #962368.](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/962368/can-still-edit-input-type-text-within-fieldset-disabled)
notes_by_num.2: File inputs that are descendants of a disabled fieldset appear disabled but the user can still interact with them. [See IE bug #817488.](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedbackdetail/view/817488)

font-variant-alternates.title: CSS font-variant-alternates
font-variant-alternates.description: Controls the usage of alternate glyphs associated to alternative names defined in @font-feature-values for certain types of OpenType fonts.

notes_by_num.1: Low-level syntax available in [font-feature-settings](http://caniuse.com/#feat=font-feature) property equivalent to OpenType features: salt, ss01 through ss20, cv01 through cv99, swsh, cswh, ornm, nalt
notes_by_num.2: Experimental support available by enabling the layout.css.font-features.enabled flag

form-attribute.title: Form attribute
form-attribute.description: Attribute for associating input and submit buttons with a form.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

es5.title: ECMAScript 5
es5.description: Full support for the ECMAScript 5 specification. Features include `Function.prototype.bind`, Array methods like `indexOf`, `forEach`, `map` & `filter`, Object methods like `defineProperty`, `create` & `keys`, the `trim` method on Strings and many more.
es5.notes: As the specification includes many JavaScript features, un-numbered partial support varies widely and is shown in detail on the [ECMAScript 5 compatibilty tables](http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es5/) by Kangax.

notes_by_num.1: Does not support `parseInt()` ignoring leading zeros.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support Strict mode
notes_by_num.3: Does not support zero-width chars in identifiers & Immutable `undefined`
notes_by_num.4: IE8 has virtually no ES5 support, but does support `Object.defineProperty`, `Object.getOwnPropertyDescriptor`, JSON parsing & Property access on strings

page-transition-events.title: PageTransitionEvent
page-transition-events.description: Fired at the Window when the page's entry in the session history stops being the current entry. Includes the `pageshow` and `pagehide` events.

ogg-vorbis.title: Ogg Vorbis audio format
ogg-vorbis.description: Vorbis is a free and open source audio format, most commonly used with the Ogg container.
ogg-vorbis.notes: Support refers to use using the `audio` element, not other conditions.

meter.title: meter element
meter.description: Method of indicating the current level of a gauge.

links.title: Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice
Examples of progress and meter elements

progress.title: progress element
progress.description: Method of indicating a progress state.

links.title: Examples of progress and meter elements

notes_by_num.1: iOS Safari does not support "indeterminate" <progress> elements.

css-filter-function.title: CSS filter() function
css-filter-function.description: This function filters a CSS input image with a set of filter functions (like blur, grayscale or hue)

css-element-function.title: CSS element() function
css-element-function.description: This function renders a live image generated from an arbitrary HTML element

notes_by_num.1: In Firefox < 4, usage limited to the background and background-image CSS properties

u2f.title: FIDO U2F API
u2f.description: Javascript API to interact with Universal Second Factor (U2F) devices. This allows users to log into sites more securely using two-factor authentication with a USB dongle.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "FIDO U2F (Universal 2nd Factor)" Chrome extension

aac.title: AAC audio file format
aac.description: Advanced Audio Coding format, designed to be the successor format to MP3, with generally better sound quality.
aac.notes: Support refers to using the `audio` element, not other conditions.

notes_by_num.1: Partial support in Firefox refers to only supporting AAC in an MP4 container and only when the operating system already has the codecs installed.

link-rel-prefetch.title: Resource Hints: prefetch
link-rel-prefetch.description: Informs the browsers that a given resource should be prefetched so it can be loaded more quickly. This is indicated using `<link rel="prefetch" href="(url)">`

links.title: Article on prefetch and other hints

ol-reversed.title: Reversed attribute of ordered lists
ol-reversed.description: This attribute makes an ordered list number its items in descending order (large to small), instead of ascending order (small to large; the default). The order that the list items are displayed in is not affected.

links.title: HTML5 Doctor article on <ol> element attributes (including reversed)
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-first-letter.title: ::first-letter CSS pseudo-element selector
css-first-letter.description: CSS pseudo-element that allows styling only the first "letter" of text within an element. Useful for implementing initial caps or drop caps styling.
css-first-letter.notes: The spec says that both letters of digraphs which are always capitalized together (such as "IJ" in Dutch) should be matched by ::first-letter, but no browser has ever implemented this.

notes_by_num.1: Excludes punctuation immediately after the first letter from the match. (The spec says it should be included in the match.)
notes_by_num.2: Acts like the first character is always a letter even when it's not. For example, given "!,X;", "!," is matched instead of the entire string.
notes_by_num.3: Only recognizes the deprecated :first-letter pseudo-class, not the ::first-letter pseudo-element.
notes_by_num.4: Only matches the very first character. The spec says that surrounding punctuation should also match.

wbr-element.title: wbr (word break opportunity) element
wbr-element.description: Represents an extra place where a line of text may optionally be broken.

const.title: const
const.description: Declares a constant with block level scope

notes_by_num.1: const is recognized, but treated like var (no block scope, can be overwritten)
notes_by_num.2: const does not have block scope
notes_by_num.3: Only recognized when NOT in strict mode
notes_by_num.4: Supported correctly in strict mode, otherwise supported without block scope

css-all.title: CSS all property
css-all.description: A shorthand property for resetting all CSS properties except for `direction` and `unicode-bidi`.

links.title: WebKit bug 116966: [css3-cascade] Add support for `all` shorthand property
Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice

css-initial-value.title: CSS initial value
css-initial-value.description: A CSS value that will apply a property's initial value as defined in the CSS specification that defines the property

css-letter-spacing.title: letter-spacing CSS property
css-letter-spacing.description: Controls spacing between characters of text (i.e. "tracking" in typographical terms). Not to be confused with kerning.

notes_by_num.1: Truncates or rounds fractional portions of values

css-unset-value.title: CSS unset value
css-unset-value.description: A CSS value that's the same as "inherit" if a property is inherited or "initial" if a property is not inherited.

links.title: WebKit bug 148614: Add support for the `unset` CSS property value

insertadjacenthtml.title: Element.insertAdjacentHTML()
insertadjacenthtml.description: Inserts a string of HTML into a specified position in the DOM relative to the given element.

notes_by_num.1: Throws an "Invalid target element for this operation." error [when called on a table, tbody, thead, or tr element.](http://ejohn.org/blog/dom-insertadjacenthtml/)

let.title: let
let.description: Declares a variable with block level scope

notes_by_num.1: Supports a non-standard version that can only be used in script elements with a type attribute of `application/javascript;version=1.7`. As other browsers do not support these types of `script` tags this makes support useless for cross-browser support.
notes_by_num.2: Requires the ‘Experimental Javascript features’ flag to be enabled
notes_by_num.3: Only supported in strict mode

arrow-functions.title: Arrow functions
arrow-functions.description: Function shorthand using `=>` syntax and lexical `this` binding.

asmjs.title: asm.js
asmjs.description: an extraordinarily optimizable, low-level subset of JavaScript, indended to be a compile target from languages like C++.

links.title: Bringing Asm.js to Chakra and Microsoft Edge

notes_by_num.1: Chrome does not support Ahead-Of-Time compilation but performance doubled in Chrome 28: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asm.js#Implementations
notes_by_num.2: Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable experimental Javascript features" flag.

lazyload.title: Resource Hints: Lazyload
lazyload.description: Gives a hint to the browser to lower the loading priority of a resource.

link-rel-dns-prefetch.title: Resource Hints: dns-prefetch
link-rel-dns-prefetch.description: Gives a hint to the browser to perform a DNS lookup in the background to improve performance. This is indicated using `<link rel="dns-prefetch" href="http://example-domain.com/">`

notes_by_num.1: IE9 [supported `dns-prefetch` as `prefetch`](http://blogs.msdn.com/b/ieinternals/archive/2012/03/01/ie10-beta-consumer-preview-minor-changes-changelist.aspx) as the former wasn’t defined yet.

link-rel-prerender.title: Resource Hints: prerender
link-rel-prerender.description: Gives a hint to the browser to render the specified page in the background, speeding up page load if the user navigates to it. This is indicated using `<link rel="prerender" href="(url)">`

rest-parameters.title: Rest parameters
rest-parameters.description: Allows representation of an indefinite number of arguments as an array.

notes_by_num.1: Requires the "Experimental Javascript features" flag to be enabled

css-cross-fade.title: CSS Cross-Fade Function
css-cross-fade.description: Image function to create a "crossfade" between images. This allows one image to transition (fade) into another based on a percentage value.

css-writing-mode.title: CSS writing-mode property
css-writing-mode.description: Property to define whether lines of text are laid out horizontally or vertically and the direction in which blocks progress.

notes_by_num.1: Internet Explorer supports different values from an [earlier version of the spec](http://www.w3.org/TR/2003/CR-css3-text-20030514/#Progression), which originated from SVG.
notes_by_num.2: Supported in Firefox under the `layout.css.vertical-text.enabled` flag

customevent.title: CustomEvent
customevent.description: A DOM event interface that can carry custom application-defined data.

links.title: Polyfill based on the MDN snippet
EventListener polyfill which includes a CustomEvent polyfill

customevent.notes: Not supported in some versions of Android's old WebKit-based WebView.

notes_by_num.1: While a `window.CustomEvent` object exists, it cannot be called as a constructor. Instead of `new CustomEvent(...)`, you must use `e = document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` and then `e.initCustomEvent(...)`
notes_by_num.2: There is no `window.CustomEvent` object, but `document.createEvent('CustomEvent')` still works.

textcontent.title: Node.textContent
textcontent.description: DOM Node property representing the text content of a node and its descendants
textcontent.notes: `Node.textContent` is somewhat similar to, but has important differences from, the proprietary [`Node.innerText`](http://caniuse.com/#feat=innertext) property.

addeventlistener.title: EventTarget.addEventListener()
addeventlistener.description: The modern standard API for adding DOM event handlers. Introduced in the DOM Level 2 Events spec. Also implies support for the [capture phase](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-event-capturing_phase) of DOM event dispatch.

notes_by_num.1: IE<=8 instead only supports the [proprietary `.attachEvent()` method](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms536343%28VS.85%29.aspx). It also does not support the [capture phase](http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#event-flow) of DOM event dispatch; it only supports event bubbling.
notes_by_num.2: The `useCapture` parameter is non-optional and must be provided. Future versions made it optional, with a default value of `false`.

dispatchevent.title: EventTarget.dispatchEvent
dispatchevent.description: Method to programmatically trigger a DOM event.

notes_by_num.1: Supports Microsoft's proprietary [`EventTarget.fireEvent() method`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/fireEvent).

documenthead.title: document.head
documenthead.description: Convenience property for accessing the `<head>` element

innertext.title: Node.innerText
innertext.description: A currently-nonstandard property representing the text within a DOM element and its descendants. As a getter, it approximates the text the user would get if they highlighted the contents of the element with the cursor and then copied to the clipboard.

links.title: WHATWG Compatibility Standard issue #5: spec innerText
Rangy, a JS range and selection library which contains an innerText implementation
Standardizing innerText – Web Incubator Community Group (WICG) discussion
Firefox bug #264412: Add support for element.innerText

innertext.notes:
This test only checks that the property exists and works correctly in a very simple case.
[This blog post by kangax](http://perfectionkills.com/the-poor-misunderstood-innerText/) explains the history of this property, gives much more detailed cross-browser compatibility information, and gives a detailed strawman specification for the property.
`Node.innerText` is similar to, but has some important differences from, the standard [`Node.textContent`](http://caniuse.com/#feat=textcontent) property.

link-rel-preconnect.title: Resource Hints: preconnect
link-rel-preconnect.description: Gives a hint to the browser to begin the connection handshake (DNS, TCP, TLS) in the background to improve performance. This is indicated using `<link rel="preconnect" href="https://example-domain.com/">`

notes_by_num.1: Firefox 39 did not support 'crossorigin' attribute and preconnects were not processed by the preload parser. Both of these features were enabled in Firefox 41.

netinfo.title: Network Information API
netinfo.description: The Network Information API enables web applications to access information about the network connection in use by the device.
netinfo.notes: In Chrome the API is enabled on Android only, support for other platforms [is coming](https://docs.google.com/a/chromium.org/document/d/1LTk9uVMGi4kurzcF5ellsAJReTF31fFJMHrQwSVtBjc/) . Support is also available on [Firefox OS](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=960426).

notes_by_num.1: Supports only the `navigator.connection.type` value which doesn't match the latest spec. [see details](http://davidbcalhoun.com/2010/using-navigator-connection-android/)

setimmediate.title: Efficient Script Yielding: setImmediate()
setimmediate.description: Yields control flow without the minimum delays enforced by setTimeout

es6-number.title: ES6 Number
es6-number.description: Extensions to the `Number` built-in object in ES6, including constant properties `EPSILON`, `MIN_SAFE_INTEGER`, and `MAX_SAFE_INTEGER`, and methods ` isFinite`, `isInteger`, `isSafeInteger`, and `isNaN`.

links.title: New number and Math features in ES6

notes_by_num.1: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite`, `isInteger`, and `isNaN` methods.
notes_by_num.2: Partial refers to supporting the same as #1 and the addition of the `EPSILON` property.
notes_by_num.3: Partial refers to supporting all new features except the `isSafeInteger` method.
notes_by_num.4: Partial refers to only supporting the `isFinite` and `isNaN` methods.

maxlength.title: maxlength attribute for input and textarea elements
maxlength.description: Declares an upper bound on the number of characters the user can input. Normally the UI ignores attempts by the user to type in additional characters beyond this limit.

notes_by_num.1: `<textarea>`'s' UI does not prevent the user from typing additional characters beyond the `maxlength` limit.
notes_by_num.2: Does not support the `HTMLTextAreaElement.maxLength` DOM property.
notes_by_num.3: Does not support [`ValidityState.tooLong`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ValidityState/tooLong). In some cases, this is because `.validity` is not supported in the first place.
notes_by_num.4: Does not support `ValidityState.tooLong` correctly in the (unlikely) case of the value being initially set too long, then changed by the user to a still incorrect state. See [Firefox bug](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1203844) and [MS Edge bug](https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedback/details/1776779).
notes_by_num.5: `<input>`'s UI does not prevent the user from typing additional characters beyond the `maxlength` limit between two existing characters of the string.
notes_by_num.6: Allows text beyond maxlength to be entered at first, but removes all characters past the maxlength when focus is lost.
